Award.AbstractNarration:
This National Science Foundation award provides support for the first Upstate New York Topology Seminar (UNYTS) that will take place at the University at Albany, State University of New York, on Saturday and Sunday, November 10-11, 2018. The state of New York is home to one of the largest collections of colleges and universities in the country, and many of these institutions in upstate New York are just far enough apart to make regular and sustained interactions between departments with active topology programs difficult. In recent years, a number of promising early-career topologists have started tenure-track positions in these departments. This, coupled with the phenomenal recent growth in applications of topology, creates the potential for bringing many new researchers into topological fields and producing significant ground-breaking work. With this award, the principle investigators seek to foster the development of newcomers to topology and increase the level of interaction among all researchers in topology in upstate New York by creating an annual series of weekend conferences. These conferences will highlight work done by New York topologists, and will also provide New York topologists with the opportunity to interact with each other and with established and emerging leaders in the field.

The conference will feature eight 45-minute plenary lectures accessible to an audience of algebraic, applied, and geometric topologists. The speakers are chosen so that participants will have the opportunity to learn about recent work in a wide range of fields within topology. Question and answer sessions following the talks will enable participants to engage in productive conversations with both the speakers and other attendees. Ample breaks along with conference breakfasts and a dinner will catalyze interactions between speakers and participants and encourage informal exchanges of ideas. The conference website may be found at https://www.albany.edu/~mv312143/unyts/.

This award reflects NSF's statutory mission and has been deemed worthy of support through evaluation using the Foundation's intellectual merit and broader impacts review criteria.

POR.DRECONTENT:
The Upstate New York Topology Seminar (UNYTS) was held at the University at Albany, State University of New York, on November 10-11, 2018. The conference featured 8 plenary lectures on current research in algebraic, applied, and geometric topology. These plenary lectures were given by Henry Adams (Colorado State University), Julie Bergner (University of Virginia), Ben Knudsen (Harvard University), Elizabeth Munch (Michigan State University), Pedro Ontaneda (Binghamton University, SUNY), Timothy Riley (Cornell), Nick Salter (Columbia University), and Inna Zakharevich (Cornell University). There were 73 participants from 27 institutions in Colorado, Indiana, Kentucky, Massachusetts, Michigan, Minnesota, New York, Ohio, Ontario, Pennsylvania, Virginia, and Wisconsin. Abstracts and participants may be found on the UNYTS webpage: https://www.albany.edu/~mv312143/unyts/.

Our objective was to increase opportunities for applied, algebraic, and geometric topologists from upstate New York to interact with one another, share ideas, and learn about recent work in all three areas. The Upstate New York Topology Seminar provided a venue for doing this. Of the participants, 71% were from institutions in New York.With the funding from this award, we sought in particular to support the attendance of early-career participants, individuals from historically underrepresented groups, and those without access to travel support. We were able to provide support to cover the costs of travel and housing to 31 of the 73 participants, including 18 PhD students and 10 early-career participants (post-doctoral fellows and assistant professors). Thirteen of these individuals were members of historically underrepresented groups.

The Upstate New York Topology Seminar gave participants the opportunity to learn about new work in the fields of applied, algebraic, and geometric topology, and to interact with a range of experts, including PhD students, post-docs, tenure-track and retired faculty members, in these fields. With plenary lectures in algebraic K-theory, abstract homotopy theory, applied topology, geometric group theory, and geometric and manifold topology, participants were able to learn about recent breakthroughs in fields both within and outside their areas of expertise. With several extended breaks and a conference dinner, participants were able to engage in informal conversations to share their ideas, start and continue collaborations, and learn about the work of others.
